description.narrative: renforcer les capacités du Ministère de la Santé, de la Population et de la Réforme Hospitalière (MSPRH) pour faire face à la pandémie du Covid-19 par l’acquisition de matériels et équipements médicaux. Le projet prévoit des provisions connexes de formations pratiques ciblées relatives à l’utilisation des équipements sanitaires et au renforcement des capacités de la PCH dans le domaine de l’achat de matériel médical et produits pharmaceutiques à travers l’expérience de la Centrale d’achat du PNUD.

To increase awareness and compliance with measures to minimize the impact of Covid-19 especially among disadvantaged segments of Nepali society
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: Number of people especially among disadvantaged segments reached through Covid-19 awareness programmes.

comment.narrative: In the front of COVID response, ESP conducted 8 episodes of webinars focusing on issues faced by disadvantaged segments reaching out to 790 participants. Each episode was focused on one particular group including women, PWD, LGBTIQ, informal workers, senior citizens, marginalized among others. A comprehensive report along with infographics were prepared (based on surveys' findings) and disseminated with UN agencies and stakeholders and uploaded in UNDP and JtF website.

description.narrative: Support NHRC’s high-level network in monitoring human rights situation with reference to COVID 19 pandemic.
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative: 1. Technical support to NHRC’s high-level network in monitoring human rights situation with reference to COVID 19. 2. Develop human rights monitoring checklist and a Working Procedure 2020 guideline of the network to monitor human rights situation with reference to COVID 19. 3. Conduct psychosocial counseling and mental health training to conflict affected community in Seven provinces. 4. 3 Crisis and disaster law reviewed from human rights perspective. 5. Conduct monitoring of the detention, old person shelters, correction centers in reference with Covid-19 by joint monitoring team. 6. Conduct study on human rights situation of vulnerable people 7. Support in digitalization system to NHRC through developing apps and ICT for virtual meeting among concerned and hotline to receive the complaints.

comment.narrative: 1. Provide in secretariat and technical support to NHRC’s high-level network in monitoring human rights situation with reference to COVID 19. 2. Develop human rights monitoring checklist and a Working Procedure 2020 guideline of the network to monitor human rights situation with reference to COVID 19. 3. Conduct psychosocial counseling and mental health training to conflict affected community in Seven provinces. 4. 3 Crisis and disaster law reviewed from human rights perspective. 5. Conduct monitoring of the detention, old person shelters, correction centers in reference with Covid-19 by joint monitoring team. 6. Conduct study on human rights situation of vulnerable people 7. Support in digitalization system to NHRC through developing apps and ICT for virtual meeting among concerned and hotline to receive the complaints.

1. A total of 85 network in monitoring human rights situation with reference to COVID 19 comprised of 450 (Male: 350 Female 100) members were supported 2. Human rights PSA through local 34 FM stations in 14 local language broadcasted. 3. One human rights monitoring checklist and a Working Procedure 2020 guideline of the network to monitor human rights situation with reference to COVID 19 developed. 4. Conducted virtual psychosocial counseling and mental health training in Seven provinces for a total of 181 conflict affect victims including 110 women. 5. 3 laws related to Infectious Disease, Disaster Risk and Management Act and Public Health Service Act reviewed from Social Security and Human Rights Perspective. 6. 5 monitoring missions in regard with human rights situation in district, human rights situation of migrant workers, detainees people with disability conducted in 28 districts. 7. Conducted two studies on human rights situation of persons with disability and rights of migrant workers in clutches of covid-19 and recommended the government to intervene activities to ensure rights of these people. 8. Human rights app developed and 10 virtual video conferencing system developed to replace paper-based complaint receiving into new innovation.

1. Conduct inductions and orientations to the members of NHRC province officials and members of human rights networks (of Sudurpaschim Province) on checklists, practitioners guide and GESI. 2. Develop and disseminate the human rights situation report in reference with Covid-19 pandemic. 3. Preparation and distribution of a code of conduct (Do's and Don’ts) to the members of human rights networks. 4. Disseminate the human rights app among people through mobile SMS and workshops.

description.narrative: 1. Nombre de personnes connectées aux plateformes multidimentionnelles incluant les videoconférences 2. Nombre de personnes employées de l'Administration ayant participé à des réunion en ligne pendant la période du COVID-19 3.Existance d'un document technique sur la mise en place d'un mecanisme de signature electronique

comment.narrative: 1. 65 2. TBD 3. No Le processus d'acqsutions des plateformes est en cours, des facilités d'accès à l'Internet sont opérationlles pour tous les services en première ligne de la crise du COVID-19. Une application pour la communication interne à l'Administration a été developée. 100 licences zooms ont été acquises. 50 modems pont été acquis 65 services ont eu la capacités de connexion pasé de 2,5 à 10 MBS soit plus de 650 personnes bénéficiant de l'accès à l'Internet à haut débit

Les institutions publiques clés et les autorités locales impliquées dans la réponse contre le COVID 19 ont leurs capacites techniques renforcées et modernisées pour qu’ils continuent d’assurer leur mission à travers la continuité des services à la population;

description.narrative: 1 - # PPE items distributed 2 - Indicator 1.1.3.6: Whether the country has increased investments to strengthen social protection systems to safeguard the most vulnerable population groups with a direct effect on income or access to services

comment.narrative: 1 - 2000 PPE items distributed 2 - Indicator 1.1.3.6: Whether the country has increased investments to strengthen social protection systems to safeguard the most vulnerable population groups with a direct effect on income or access to services = yes

1 - In early May, the project supplied more than 8,700 bottles of hand gel and 260 temperature screeners to the Union and State/Region level Parliaments, and to government organizations such as the ACC, the UAGO, the OSCU, the MNHRC and other counterparts. Similar assistance was also provided to its 12 CSO partners in Kachin, Northern Shan and Rakhine States. Following the recent outbreak of the virus in August, IPs in Rakhine were assisted with additional PPE. This included 8 PPE suits, 11000 masks, 230 bottles of hand sanitizer, 6200 pairs of gloves, 150 surgical head-covers, 170 face shields and 60 bottles of disinfectant spray. 2 - Indicator 1.1.3.6: Whether the country has increased investments to strengthen social protection systems to safeguard the most vulnerable population groups with a direct effect on income or access to services = yes

2 - Indicator 1.1.3.6: Whether the country has increased investments to strengthen social protection systems to safeguard the most vulnerable population groups with a direct effect on income or access to services = yes

description.narrative:
Indicator 1.1.3.4: Whether the country undertook socio-economic impact assessments in response to the COVID-19 crisis, with a focus on vulnerable groups, directed at-risk populations.
Indicator 1.1.3.5: Whether the country is implementing policies informed by socio-economic impact assessment, directed at-risk populations

comment.narrative:
Indicator 1.1.3.4: 0 Whether the country undertook socio-economic impact assessments in response to the COVID-19 crisis, with a focus on vulnerable groups, directed at-risk populations.
Indicator 1.1.3.5: 0 Whether the country is implementing policies informed by socio-economic impact assessment, directed at-risk populations

Indicator 1.1.3.4 : 2 (COVID KAP Assessment and Labor Market Survey) Whether the country undertook socio-economic impact assessments in response to the COVID-19 crisis, with a focus on vulnerable groups, directed at-risk populations.
Indicator 1.1.3.5 : 15 policy briefs and Development and Approval of Azme Nau (KP Economic Recovery Plan) Whether the country is implementing policies informed by socio-economic impact assessment, directed at-risk populations

Indicator 1.1.3.4 : 2 Conducted COVID impact assessment study in collaboration with Planning and Development Department of KP. The impact assessment assessed the impact of COVID-19 on different sectors of the economy with particular focus on labor class and at risk population. MAGP also conducted the labor market survey to assess the impact of COVID-19 on Labor market
Indicator 1.1.3.5 : 15 Policy briefs developed and Azme Nau, The KP economic recovery plan developed approved and implemented. 1. Provided policy support to the government of KP through 15 policy briefs and notes (Vital Economic Operations Management) containing policy inputs for the KP government, for implementing informed socio economic assessment. Until the end of December the KP government has taken 11 economic policy related decision based on the policy inputs provided to the government in the VEOM policy briefs.
2. Supported the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Government for the development of the Azm-e-Nau Economic Recovery Plan. Valued at PKR 29 billion ($175 million), the plan will be implemented over the next three years.

Indicator 1.1.3.4 : 1 (Dissemination/knowledge sharing of the COVID KAP survey with the relevant stakeholders) Whether the country undertook socio-economic impact assessments in response to the COVID-19 crisis, with a focus on vulnerable groups, directed at-risk populations.
Indicator 1.1.3.5: 1 (Azme Nau economic recovery plan is being implemented-MAGP provides support in implementation of Azme nau) Whether the country is implementing policies informed by socio-economic impact assessment, directed at-risk populations

led in preparing budget estimates and advise on priorities prior to submission, ensuring that adequate recoveries are included; − provided strategic support for fund mobilization through relationships with key donors (institutional, private and public appeals); − provided support to proposal development, approval and donor relations where required; − provided FGS and Response Team technical leads members with communications materials to use in public appeals and other fundraising activities; − monitoring fundraising targets and strategy on behalf of the FGS.
Well-equipped Call Centre: I. A call centre which is able to receive calls from all over the country divided into three sectors consisting of: A) a group of consultation which provides general advise to people requesting general information; B) a group guiding and advising people with symptoms; and C) group of senior doctors dealing with special cases.

Updated: 28.12.2020 • Conducted a series of meeting with Rakhine State Government (Chief Minister, Planning Minister and Social Affair Minister) and Rakhine State Health and Sport Department (Director of DOHS and MS of Sittwe General Hospital) for updating, analyzing, exploring and the identifying the opportunities for partnership with UNDP and Rakhine State Government since March 2020. • Oxygen Plant and Patient Monitors have been identified to provide under JSB fund. • For Oxygen Plant procurement, procurement process has been completedreceived 3 bidders (one from USA and two based in Myanmar) for different types of oxygen plants. Since the price of the one from USA was beyond our approved budget though good quality, there were only two bidders; Okkar Thiri Company and Fourteen Stars Company in the final selection. • Based on the recommendations of technicians from Sittwe General Hospital, DOHS and panel members, Fourteen Stars Company was selected as recommended supplier for Oxygen plant (Oxygen Plant from Greece and Compressor from Italy). Supplier has signed agreement in November and installation will start in the second week of January 2021. • For Patient Monitors, as per the agreement between UNDP and RSG/DOHS, we have already selected a supplier Kathit Htoo Company from 6 bidders for 12 units of Patient monitors. It is also expected to arrive at the same time of Oxygen plant installation in January 2021.
Indicator 3.1.2.1: Number of government entities supported to ensure business continuity and provision of basic and social services during the COVID-19 pandemic. B) Subnational = 1

comment.narrative: 1 - A film produced 2 - Indicator 1.1.3.6: Whether the country has increased investments to strengthen social protection systems to safeguard the most vulnerable population groups with a direct effect on income or access to services = yes

1 - A short-animated film on Covid-19 stigma was developed in cooperation with the YFS. The video features the real experience of a young woman migrant worker returning from China and who faced stigma from her community. The film is finalised and will be disseminated through social media and potentially later through TV. You can view the film here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2DCzd0jJk_c. 2 - Indicator 1.1.3.6: Whether the country has increased investments to strengthen social protection systems to safeguard the most vulnerable population groups with a direct effect on income or access to services = yes

comment.narrative: The Saudi government had already identified 21 challenges in nine sectors related to social, economic, and environmental dimensions, along with identified enablers

To support Saudi youth fellows residing all over the world, in designing and implementing innovative initiatives that promote the SDGs and contribute to the Saudi government’s efforts in addressing SDG’s national challenges and priorities.

Mentoring the youth to design solutions for SDGs. 92 participants divided across 17 teams made it to the final evaluation/judgment ceremony, with solutions covering 10 challenges after attending 239 mentoring sessions and five capacity building trainings, and interacting with 31 mentors and advisors.

description.narrative:
Indicator 2.3.3.1 Number of digital solutions adopted to address the COVID-19 pandemic
2.3.3.1 Scale 1: No Helpline/Portal for addressing needs of COVID-19 patients 2.3.3.1 Scale 2: One functional provincial helpline/portal for addressing needs of COVID-19 patients 2.3.3.1 Scale 3: Two functional helplines/portals (Provincial or Federal) for addressing needs of COVID-19 patients 2.3.3.1 Scale 4: Three functional helplines/portals (Provincial or Federal) for addressing needs of COVID-19 patients 2.3.3.1 Scale 5: Helpline/portal established for each province (Four in total)

comment.narrative: Baseline 2.3.3.1 Scale 1: No Helpline/Portal for addressing needs of COVID19 patients
2.3.3.1 Scale 2: One functional provincial helpline/portal for addressing needs of COVID-19 patients

2.1: Scale Item 2: Helpline 1093 and online portal established in the Sindh Local Government Department provide psychosocial support to persons affected by COVID-19, their families and front line health workers.

2.3.3.1 Scale 3: Two functional helplines/portals (Provincial or Federal) for addressing needs of COVID-19 patients
(Helpline providing psychosocial support to persons affected by COVID-19 established in Islamabad, Sindh 1093 Helpline and online portal continue support at the provincial level)

description.narrative: Number of PICTs with RTI regimes supported/ advanced Number of PICTs with active anticorruption youth initiatives Number of stories citing multiple sources and referring to internationally recognized documents and indicators Number of PICTs where the regulatory barriers to meritocracy and accountability have been removed through an updated regulatory framework Percentage of new recruits in public service trained on the regulatory framework Number of PICTs with improved transparency and accountability in the management of public finances Number of PICTs with improved public reporting including proactive supply of information and data by government, transparency of decision-making processes and outcomes Number of PICTs with people effectiveness strategies implemented in the public sector Number of entities that have undertaken risk assessments Number of sectors that have introduced integrity and compliance measures Number of PICTs strengthened ethics in women-owned businesses Number of women-owned businesses with strengthened internal control mechanisms and compliance

comment.narrative: PICTs has an RTI regime (Vanuatu) PICTs have active anti-corruption youth initiatives (Kiribati, Solomon Islands, Vanuatu) Minimal corruption related reporting in print media; social media used but often with single source Lack of accountable and meritocratic systems incl. regulations effectively administered Public service induction trainings are held in most PICTs Weak management of public finances in the majority of PICTs Weak public reporting in public service institutions No PICTs with people effectiveness strategies implemented in the public sector No risk assessments undertaken in the majority of Pacific public and private sector entities Lack of integrity and compliance measures in key sectors Lack of information on PICTs strengthened ethics in women-owned businesses Lack of information on number of women-owned business with strengthened internal control mechanisms and compliance

description.narrative: Appui aux deux Instances pour qu'elles puissent répondre plus efficacement aux conséquences liées à la crise COVID19
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Accelerate structural transformations

description.narrative:
L’effet 2 : Variation du nombre des tunisiens.nes qui saisissent les Instances (cible=10% de progression) Produit 2.1 : Ind 2.1.1. Nombre de passages télé et radio des spots vidéo et audio inclusifs (cible=80) Ind 2.1.2. Nombre de visualisations sur les réseaux sociaux et site web des spots vidéo (cible=1,000,000) Produit 2.2 : Ind 2.2.1. % de la population considérant la torture une atteinte aux droits humains (cible=20%) Ind 2.2.2. % de la population qui considère les traitements cruels, inhumains ou dégradants comme étant des atteintes aux droits humains (cible=20%)
L’effet 3 : Nombre de nouvelles publications/instance/an (cible=10) Produit 3.1 : Ind 3.1.1 - Nombre de publications, prenant en compte l’inclusion, avant la fin du projet (cible=10)

comment.narrative:
L’effet 2 : Les populations, en particulier les populations directement concernées par les interventions des Instances, sollicitent leurs interventions et accèdent à leurs services respectifs Cet effet comporte les produits suivants : Produit 2.1 : Les populations, en particulier celles directement concernées par les interventions des Instances, y compris les femmes, les jeunes et les groupes vulnérables, sont mieux informées et sensibilisées sur les rôles respectifs des Instances, leurs prérogatives et modalités de saisine et d’intervention. Produit 2.2: Les populations, en particulier celles directement concernées par les interventions des Instances, y compris les femmes, les jeunes et les groupes vulnérables, sont mieux informées et sensibilisées sur leurs droits et les risques liés à la torture et à la traite des personnes
L’effet 3 : L’instance nationale pour la prévention de la torture (INPT) et de l’Instance nationale de lutte contre la traite des personnes (INLTP) produisent et partagent des connaissances en matière de prévention de la torture et de la lutte contre la traite des personnes Cet effet comporte les produits suivants : Produit 3.1?: Des recherches en lien avec la prévention de la torture et la lutte contre la traite des personnes sont réalisées et diffusées
nb de videos produites (sensibilisation, communication) = 4 nb d'événement organisés = 4

l’INPT a présenté son mandat au grand public et de présenter l’approche qu’elle a suivi dans sa réponse à la pandémie en assurant les visites préventives aux lieux de privation de liberté et aux centres de confinement pour s’assurer du respect des droits humains et de l’inexistence de pratiques ou traitements inhumains, cruels ou dégradants lors de l’application des mesures restrictives à cause de la COVID-19. 4 événements de sensibilisation organisés Annonce du prix Mandela qui sera décerné annuellement par l’INPT en collaboration avec l’Ambassade de l’Afrique du Sud en Tunisie Production et diffusion de vidéos inclusives sur e rôle des instances

description.narrative: a. Number of comprehensive assessments report to identify MSMEs impacted by the pandemic and data base set up. b. 5000 youths (60% women) with enhanced awareness on vocational training and assisted with start-up grants for small businesses related to COVID-19 response including Hygiene and sanitation materials c. Number of online mobile platforms set up for MSMEs for enhanced virtual service provisions/ improvements. d. Number of integrated MSMEs with supply chains with industrial parks for better income. e. Number of “one window” service established by the Government in the regions on SMEs supported.

comment.narrative: a. There is very little data on the impact of the pandemic on MSMEs in order to set up a data base and enable small business to regain their productivity b. Small enterprises mostly of women owned are unable to become self-supportive and incapable due to COVID-19 pandemic c. Lack of functioning online mobile platform for MSMEs for an enhanced virtual service provisions/ improvement. d. Lack of integration of MSMEs with supply chains for industrial parks e. Lack of functional capacity of a “one window” service established by the Government in the regions on SMEs.

α. At least 1 socio-economic impact report on the pandemic is accessible and used to set up a data base on MSMEs. b. 5000 youths (60% women) are supported through vocational training and with business startup capital c. one functional online mobile platform for MSMEs is established /installed for enhanced virtual service provisions/ improvements. d. three or more MSMEs are integrated with supply chains through industrial parks. e. At least one “one window” services established by the Government in the regions on SMEs are reinforced through capacity building process.

description.narrative: 1. Reinforcing the national COVID-19 response through procurement of PPE including N95 Masks, surgical masks, half-faced masks, hand & surface sanitizer, latex gloves, needle and syringes, face shield, medical gown, infrared- thermometer, pulse oximeter, disposable shoe cover, sprayer, and condom. 2. Improvements in health and community systems and supports the country to respond impact of COVID-19 among the most vulnerable population through the procurement of medical devices including Viral load Machine, CD4 Machines, GeneXpert Machines, and cartridges.

comment.narrative:
2020 Targets:
1. PPE - N95 Masks: 12,000 (Pcs) - Surgical masks: 332,615 (Pcs) - Half-faced masks: 120 (Pcs) - Alcohol-based hand sanitizer: 11,800 (Bottle of 500 cc) - Surface sanitizer: 6,590 (Bottle of 4 liter) - Latex gloves: 13,800 (Pcs) - Needle and syringes: 1,151,820 (Pcs) - Face shield: 4,900 (Pcs) - Medical gown: 5,840 (Pcs) - Infrared- thermometer: 1,192 (Pcs) - Pulse oximeter: 240 (Pcs) - Disposable shoe cover: 108,000 (Pcs) - Sprayer: 700 (Pcs) - Electric sprayer: 20 (Pcs) - Condom: 20,000 (Packs of 144)
2. Medical devices: - Viral load Machine: 5 - CD4 Machines: 12 - GeneXpert Machines: 4 - GeneXpert cartridges: 14,500

description.narrative: # of women provided with health care insurance and work accident insurance.

comment.narrative: # of women provided with health care insurance and work accident insurance. BL: 0

- Provide 48 women with health care insurance and work accident insurance. - Conduct a rapid survey and impact assessment of COVID-19 on the communities in the designated municipalities. - Enhance the engagement of 80 women in responding to C19 through designing and implementing women-led community health initiatives. - Hire a consultant to develop an action plan for the WEE units to support in the immediate activities that will be implemented under the project.

- 48 women were provided with health care insurance and work accident insurance. - A rapid survey and impact assessment of COVID-19 on the communities in the designated municipalities was conducted. - 80 Women were enaged in responding to C19 through designing and implementing women-led community health initiatives were enhanced. - A consultant was hired to develop an action plan for the WEE units to support in the immediate activities that will be implemented under the project
- Develop a capacity building plans and Annual Action Plans for 4 WEE units.

description.narrative: The project will support the relevant Government entities to possess sufficient capacity to support the COVID-19 response for reducing the spread and controlling the complications and deaths through provision of PPEs.

description.narrative: Ensure uninterrupted service delivery and prevent transmission of COVID-19 through procurement of Personal Protective Equipment materials (PPE), medical and diagnostic equipment for health and social service providers, CSOs, hospitals and schools.

comment.narrative: 1. Number of health facilities/service delivery centers that benefit from improved supplies of PPE: 2,511 centers 2. Number of health workers in target facilities who will have improved access to PPE: 11,370 Health staff as direct beneficiaries of PPEs.
